Log submissions rise, a testament to the campaign's success.

Yet, the struggle to sustain the momentum of the project is a relentless foe, compounded by the rhythms of holiday and semester breaks that define the world of higher learning. Another adversary lies in the hearts of men and women, a deep-seated love of the freedom and independence found behind the wheel of their own cars. It is a cultural tenet, a truth not easily swayed. To entice the masses towards alternative paths, incentives must be laid out like treasures. Gift certificates to local haunts, restaurants, coffee shops, and beyond were offered, their allure undeniable. Yet, one wonders what might have been wrought by grander prizes—a bicycle, a hybrid, or even an electric car—vehicles of change that could alter the course of engagement.

Throughout, the nature of the prizes remained a constant, unchanging as the seasons. But what if the stakes had risen? If in December bicycles had been announced, and by the time January arrived, hints of hybrid or electric cars danced before the eyes of the participants? One can only ponder how the numbers might have swelled, how the engagement might have transformed from decline to resurgence. The promise of such rewards might have held the key to a different tale.

In the archives of the Library of Congress lies a collection of early Edison films, wherein I found myself drawn to the trick films, fifteen in all, spanning the years from 1895 to 1901. These films are a testament to the art of illusion, crafted through the cleverness of editing. My study delved into the poetics that pervade the majority of these films, while also casting an eye toward those few that stand as evolutionary outliers. At the dawn of the century, the trick film remained tethered to its stagebound roots, framed by a frontal proscenium, absent of camera movement, comprised of long and medium shots, adhering to the principle of one shot equating to one film. Yet, as the century turned, there emerged films that dared to defy these conventions, introducing the notion of multiple shots.

What binds these trick films together is their steadfast reliance on the interior set within the confines of a proscenium frame. The camera, resolute in its position, refuses to pursue figures or objects beyond its fixed gaze. This composition harks back to the theatre, to vaudeville, and to magic acts, where the stage is both a boundary and a canvas. The constraint of the stage renders the movement of figures in trick films to a horizontal plane, a dance from side to side, never venturing towards or away from the camera. Consider the film Uncle Josh in a Spooky Hotel from the year 1900. The actors enter from the right, traversing back and forth, yet the camera remains unmoved, indifferent to their absence when they slip beyond its frame.

The proscenium's grip ensures that shots are predominantly long, occasionally medium, but never close. The theatre and vaudeville influence persists, where the audience bears witness to the entirety of the performance, framed by the stage's borders. In these early films, actors remain anchored to the middle ground, eschewing the intimacy of close-ups.

In the nascent days of cinema, trick films followed a simple creed: one conceptual shot equals a film. This confines most to a fleeting minute or less, dictated by the frames per second. It also curtails the dramatic or narrative ambitions, focusing instead on brief vaudevillian tricks—acts of magic, disappearance, and transformation, stories left untold. Yet, in the realm of trick films, one must remember that one conceptual shot does not always equate to one physical shot. A single "shot" may be a seamless tapestry of fragments, conjuring the illusion of appearing or vanishing. Observe The Execution of Mary, Queen of Scots from 1895. A closer look betrays the moment where Mary's severed "head" graces the screen, though to the viewer, the film remains a singular shot.

In the shadowed corridors of literary history, the Gothic Novel stands as a curious beacon, an oxymoron of old and new as Ian Watt might say in his chronicling of such tales. This mode, both reviled and revered, accused of shallowness yet celebrated for its terrible sublimity, finds its origins in Horace Walpole’s The Castle of Otranto. Here, ancient and modern are woven together to birth a new form, a Gothic Story as Walpole christened it, a tapestry of old theatrics and the mimicry of the natural world as seen through the eyes of modern literary minds. The Gothic, with its nods to medieval theatre and architecture, dances in the archaic light of its own making, a relic unsophisticated in the face of modernity’s march. Yet, it is this very duality, the theatrical Gothic entwined with the intimacy of the novel’s form, that grants it longevity, a relic both obsolete and reborn for readers adrift in time.

Amongst the echoes of its pages, chivalry rises as a specter, a vestige of medieval knighthood both preserved and reshaped in Walpole’s creation. The Gothic writers, drawn to this ideal of bravery and honor, saw in the chivalric past a mirror held to their own disenchanted world. The Gothic past becomes a canvas for idealization, a precursor to the Romantic that sought to mend the present's ills. Walpole, writing amidst political unrest, saw the chivalric virtues as a balm for society’s wounds, a lost morality in the din of the present. This yearning is etched in characters like Frederic, a figure painted with strokes of chivalric imagery—a prince, a sufferer of tragedies, a presumed casualty of infidels. In Frederic, the gallant and courteous knight is an exaggerated echo, a portent of the Gothic’s embrace of excess, a myth made flesh within the pages of Otranto.

Thus, in the Gothic Novel, we find an edifice built from the stones of the past, a shadowed testament to the old and the new, a bridge to the realms of what was and what might yet be.

In the vast and unyielding landscape of commerce, there exists a journey that is neither seen nor heard, yet it moves the world. It is the procession of goods and dreams, from the whispered wants of the customer to the raw earth, through the alchemy of creation and the endless march to the waiting hands of the buyer. This is the domain of supply chain management, a name coined by the prophet Keith Oliver in the year of our Lord nineteen hundred and eighty-two. In his vision, he saw the whole of it, the grand orchestration of planning and action, a dance to satisfy the unceasing hunger of the market. There are six pillars upon which this edifice is built: the birth of goods, their provision, their hoarding, their place, their passage, and the knowledge that binds them. On these the manager must lean, to craft a service that speaks to the heart of the customer.

First among these is production, the genesis. It is the bedrock upon which all else rests. Here the when and the why, the where and the how are carved into the stone of intention. The steward of this stage must read the stars, the market, to divine the desires of the people. In this knowing, they chart the course of what shall be made and in what measure. Once the prophecy is clear, they choose the place of creation, the forge best suited to the task. And in this choosing, they heed the twin gods of demand and satisfaction. Then comes the reckoning of labor and the tending of machines, a schedule drawn from the marrow of necessity. Every thread in this tapestry is vital, for a single flaw may unravel the whole. I have walked the aisles of Wal-Mart and Target, where every thread is woven with care, each process a solemn rite. Such is the power of design, a beacon against the chaos of uncertainty.

Supply, the second pillar, is the lifeblood of this endeavor. It is the calculus of strategy, the decisions that shape the bones of a facility and the alliances formed in the crucible of need. A single product may arise from many hands, each division a realm unto itself, with its own tools and toils. The master of this stage must discern which hand best suits each task. At times, the call goes beyond, to other lands, to the altars of outsourcing. For in this, there is velocity, the sacred triad of quality, flexibility, and the eternal quest for a cost that does not bleed the coffers dry. Such is the dance of supply, a testament to the will of those who shape the world unseen.

In the shadow of that bygone era, the novels of the Victorian age stand tall, their pages woven with threads of meticulous detail, their narratives steeped in the lives of the highborn. Yet, there are those tales that wander from this well-trodden path, among them Oliver Twist and Wuthering Heights, where the air of mystery hangs thick and the peculiar dances in the periphery of the ordinary. Such elements breathe life into the souls of their characters, peeling back layers to reveal the tumult beneath, the hidden urges and the ghosts of their desires.

"And now, hosts of bewildering and confusing ideas came crowding on his mind. He seemed to be still walking between Sikes and Crackit, who were angrily disputing: for the very words they said, sounded in his ears; and when he caught his own attention, ... he found that he was talking to them.... Suddenly he started back at the report of firearms; and there rose into the air loud cries and shouts; lights gleamed before his eyes, and all was noise and tumult, as some unseen hand bore him hurriedly away. Through all these rapid visions, there ran an undefined, uneasy consciousness of pain, which wearied and tormented him incessantly." (Dickens, 220)

In these tales, the shroud of mystery often descends through dreams or states akin to dreams, their nature shifting with the winds of the narrative. In the story of Oliver Twist, such visions uncover hidden truths about the boy, the shadows that haunt him, and the grim reality that encircles him. When the memory of the shooting is stirred in chapter 28, it unfurls in Oliver's mind like a fevered dream, a cruel reminder of his helplessness and the ravages upon his frail form. The phantoms of Sikes and Crackit haunt his thoughts, his senses dulled, oblivious to the unseen hand that sweeps him away. Pain has become his constant companion, a specter intertwined with fear rather than surprise. With his will subsumed, questions arise about the hand that steers his fate, a destiny not of his own making. The shooting stands as testament to Oliver's lack of agency, his inability to grasp the reins of his own survival, even as the specter of death looms. A shadow of surrender creeps into his heart, as if old Fagin's grip tightens, bending him to despair's will, stifling the fire within him that might otherwise rise in defiance.

"The day passed off – day! There was no day; it was gone as soon as come – and night came on again; night so long, and yet so short; long in its dreadful silence and short in its fleeting hours."

Years passed since I found myself in the quiet corridors of an after-school program where I took to tutoring young souls not much taller than the desks they sat at. I did what I could to guide them through the tangled thickets of subjects they found troublesome, though my own compass pointed truest toward the realms of English and reading. There was a teacher there, an instructor, who beckoned me to aid a young boy named Adrian. He was a small thing, perhaps third or fourth grade, and he wrestled with words as if they were phantoms. It struck me strange how some letters he knew with certainty, and others he could not fathom, like strangers in a familiar town. The boy was of Latino descent, that much was clear, yet his English was unblemished, flawless in speech if not in script. We toiled in that place, him and I, until the day his mother came to the school. 

I remember it well. I was tending to a few children who had not gone on some excursion with their fellows when she appeared. She spoke to me in Spanish, and though my grasp of that language was tenuous, we managed to bridge the gulf between us with the few words I did possess. It was in that moment, as if struck by an epiphany, I realized Adrian's struggle was no enigma of reading, but of familiarity with the English alphabet itself. Whether this revelation bore fruit for him in the years to come, I cannot say. Yet I wish him well and trust that the world treated him kindly.

This tale I recount is a mirror to the broader issue of language barriers that echo through the halls of California's schools. It is a reminder that these obstacles are not always what they seem. Even for those who speak English with grace, reading it can be an insurmountable wall. We know this problem lives among us, so what path do we take? For Adrian, the answer lay in patience and guidance through the letters and sounds of English. Yet for many others, this challenge is a labyrinth with no single thread to lead them out. There is no panacea. The solution lies in weaving together a tapestry of dual language programs, immersive classrooms, private tutors, and ESL classes.

The dual language approach is a seed of promise. It is not simply for those whose first words were in Spanish, but for all children. Studies show that children in bilingual education soar above their peers. Fear clings to this idea, whispers of wasted effort and benefit to none. But if these programs were the norm instead of the outlier, all children might drink deeply from their well. How do we realize this vision? Not by demanding every teacher bear the burden of bilingualism. Such an expectation is beyond reason. But there is no barrier to enlisting aides, tutors, call them what you will, who carry both languages within them like a gift.

From the tender age when the world is new and unformed, there arises the notion of something vast and ungraspable, a specter of the infinite looming ever just beyond our ken. We are ushered into halls of worship, to Sunday schools or temples, or sent on inward journeys to seek the elusive truths that lie within. Many among us take the faith of our ancestors as our own, a mantle passed down through the ages. Yet others cast it aside, claiming the barren certainty of a world circumscribed by self. We may cling to one creed only to find it wanting and exchange it for another. Each path is a solitary pilgrimage into the recesses of our souls, a search for meaning amidst shadows, for the dawn beyond the night.

It was on the porch, the rain a steady cadence on the tin roof, that I asked my father his favored bird. "A cardinal," he said, a word spoken into the twilight with the gravity of a man who knows the weight of things unsaid. We sat there, the smoke from our cigarettes mingling with the rain's mist, the gutters a torrent drowning the garden's edge. His gaze fixed upon the falling rain, a look that spoke of seeking and remembering both. Time had thinned him, his clothes now mere drapery over a wasted frame, his hair a sparse memory of what once was. He looked away, eyes averted, and silence fell between us, a chasm I could not cross. I felt the solitude of impending loss, the words lodged in my throat, words that would make the inevitable irrevocable. I reached out, drew my chair near, and together we watched the rain descend upon the June dusk.

December came, and with it the final departure. Five days after I marked another year, my father slipped away. The treatments had been futile, a prolongation of pain that defied reason or mercy. I questioned the divine, wondered what god would allow such suffering, found no solace in the night. Prayers faltered on my lips, for if there was a god, he had turned his ear from me long ago.

I could not bear witness to his passing, the man who had given me life. I chose not to see the end, to remember him as he was, not as he became. I knew him better than those who surrounded his final hours, better than his kin, and I knew he would not wish his child to mark his end with eyes full of grief. So I withdrew, wrapped myself in solitude for three days, awaiting the inevitable word.

The silence was unbroken. No call came.

In the fields of Caroline, where the soil lay thick with the sweat of men, John Taylor stood as a sentinel of Republicanism. His hands were those of an agriculturalist, the earth beneath his nails a testament to his craft, yet his voice rang loud in the halls of politics. A man forged in the fires of his convictions, dedicated to the cause of personal freedom and the governance that would safeguard it. The land was his gospel, and from it he drew the marrow of his beliefs, seeing in its tilling the very essence of sovereignty, Constitutionality, and the laws that bind men.

Taylor gazed upon the young republic and saw a canvas unmarred by ancient rites. Here was a land unshackled, a place where self-government might take root in the rich, untrodden soil. He held fast to the natural rights of man, each right a thread in the tapestry, and if one were cut, the whole would unravel. Such rights must be held beyond the reach of government’s grasping hand. He spoke of the so-called "state of nature," where brute strength and cunning ruled, a world that civilization must transcend.

In his vision of an ideal society, Taylor called for a government that mirrored the duality of man's soul, both light and dark. His creed was simple: "As government is exercised by man, all its virtues and vices must be human." Good principles were those that guarded private property, nurtured the land, and kept the specter of capitalism at bay. A government rooted in such principles would stand firm, its course unaltered by the winds of avarice and self-interest. These were the twin engines of man’s endeavor, yet only when they built upon the public good could they be redeemed. A vigilant government was the bulwark against man's inherent darkness, ever watchful lest it stray into shadow.

Taylor, like his fellow Republicans, held fast to the Constitution’s strict construction. He envisioned a Federal government bound by chains no looser than those spelled out in its sacred text. He knew the cost of a sprawling government, its greed a harbinger of tyranny. Yet he also feared the perils of a literal reading, divorced from the minds that first penned its words. To him, the Declaration of Independence was the true charter, a testament to a union of sovereign states, not a monolithic nation. In its words, he found the promise of a republic, a promise he held as dearly as the soil beneath his feet.

I looked down into the abyss and the abyss looked back, a flat and unyielding gaze that offered no quarter nor demanded any. The mind, that treacherous vessel of reflection, churned not with thoughts but with the silent acceptance of what lay before it. There was a strange purity to the act, a consciousness unburdened by abstraction, the eyes filling and emptying in a rhythm as ancient as the earth itself. Such was the dance of perception, a fluid encounter with the world that left no trace of itself.

Once, under the guidance of a fellow creator, I took up a tome titled The New Drawing on the Right Side of the Brain. I had harbored a desire to sketch since boyhood, and this book promised to illuminate the path from the mundane to the sublime, from the humble pencil to the mysteries of line and form. It spoke of a frame, a boundary to tame the chaos of sight, to isolate a simple truth in a world of complexity. Imagine, if you will, a bowl of fruit upon a table, a still life amidst the clutter of a kitchen, reduced to its essence by the artist's square.

Yet now, as I stood before the porcelain altar, I could not conjure that frame. The enormity of it all, a visceral presence that defied containment, left me rooted in awe. Artists have their phases; Picasso with his blues, Monet with his verdant dreams, and the Renaissance with its symphony of hues. If I were to claim any such vision, it would begin here, in this Work in Brown.

My fingers brushed the tool of my creation, the muscles of my arm a conduit for the will of the mind, shaping the void in a moment that felt pure and unadulterated. The water moved, eddied in its crystalline repose, and the detritus of life surrendered to the flow. Again my hand found the handle, more insistent now, willing the recalcitrant mass to yield to its fate. But it clung stubbornly, a defiant creature in the depths.

With mop in hand, my stance firm, the tie at my neck a mark of the burden I bore, I cast a weary eye upon the refuse left behind by those who tread the aisles of Rite Aid. A few more attempts, a few more moments of contemplation, and my hand reached for the roll at my side. Layers of paper ensconced my hand, an improvised gauntlet for the task ahead. Straightening, I bent once more, my hand descending into the water like a pilgrim reaching for the holy relic buried in the earth.

In the waning light of the day, the shadows of the young stretch long across the tarmac and the hum of engines fills the air like some ancient call. They are out there, these teenagers, driving under a sky that holds no mercy, and it is here that they find themselves at the intersection of fate and folly. The National Institutes of Health speak of the unripe minds of these young drivers, their brains not yet carved for the perils of the road. Inexperience, that age-old specter, shadows their every mile, and it is this lack that leads them to calamity—vehicles overturned, the road beneath them slipping away, speed their constant companion.

In the company of their peers, the weight of wisdom seems to lift, leaving them unanchored, adrift on highways and backroads alike. The Southern California Injury Prevention Research Center has laid bare the truth with studies that draw a stark line between the age of passengers and the frequency of their misfortunes. And yet, in response, states like California erect flimsy barricades, provisional licenses that seek to hem in the chaos. But these are but reeds against the tide.

The heart of the matter lies in the very essence of youth. These young drivers, by every account and measure, stand unready for the burden they bear. Psychologist Marvin Zuckerman speaks of the wild heart beneath the breast of youth, suggesting that even at eighteen, the fire of risk still burns too bright. USA Today carries his words, a warning of the thrill-seeking urge that dances like a devil on the shoulder of the young. Delay the right to drive, he argues, until the flame subsides.

Should we continue to set these young behind the wheel, their fates will remain entwined with ruin. By 2010, the progeny of the Baby Boomers shall flood the roadways, a generation poised to steer into the unknown. The reckoning of legislation, clear and stark, waits at the horizon. Schools may still guide the hands and minds of future drivers, yet the wheels should not turn for any under eighteen. A provisional path may lead them, requiring hours of practice beneath the watchful eye of an elder. Uniform laws, drawn with a steady hand across the nation, may yet guard the youth from their own undoing.

Such laws are not new, nor are they revolutionary. They stand instead as a testament to reason, a bulwark against the encroaching dark.

In the vast expanse of human condition there lies a peculiar disorder known as Central Auditory Processing Disorder, or CAPD. The mind, that mysterious engine of perception, falters here. It is a disorder that speaks to the inefficiencies of the central nervous system, the way it stumbles over the auditory information that it is meant to decipher. The brain hears, yet does not understand, failing to separate the urgent whispers of words from the clamor of the world. Those who bear this burden hear as others do, yet the translation of sound into meaning is fraught and uncertain.

In the mid-century past, they spoke of auditory imperception, a term birthed in the studies of children whose communicative paths were obscured. Italian pioneers, Bocca, Calearo, and Cassinari, sought to unravel this enigma in 1954, and by 1961, a thinker named Kimura would introduce dichotic testing, a lens into the physiology of the central auditory nervous system. In '77, minds gathered in conference to stir this pool of understanding, to delve deeper into the mysteries of CAPD.

CAPD, in its many manifestations, is a shadowy adversary. The afflicted may find themselves adrift in sound, unable to pinpoint its source or discern its nature. The dance of acoustic events might confuse them; the subtle shifts in speech tones, the markers of sarcasm or sincerity, elude their grasp. Sounds can overlap like waves upon a shore, obscuring meaning. The sequence of auditory information, meant to guide, becomes a tangled skein.

To diagnose this disorder is no simple task, for the tools are many and the paths are unclear. Audiologists, SLPs, psychologists, and others peer into the depths of listening behaviors, seeking clarity. Yet, there is no singular test that holds the promise of certainty. The process involves observing responses to sound, discerning the nuances of auditory perception. The patient is presented with a cacophony, asked to make sense of it, to sift the signal from the noise. In some cases, the very echoes within the ear are measured, searching for that which might reveal the workings of the mind.

There remains no known cause for this disorder, no single path to diagnosis. It lingers in the shadows of understanding, a testament to the complexities of the human brain and the sounds that encompass it.

In the pursuit of a calling to social work, I've set my sights on laboring with the Division of Family and Children Services. A path laid out to shield the young from harm and to offer solace to families adrift. Values I bring forth to this field are woven with service, respect, ethical fortitude, a relentless commitment to mend the bonds between souls, and a ceaseless quest for my own betterment in this craft. These values, they are not mere words for social workers to wield; they are the very marrow of my being.

Always have I yearned to lend a hand to others, yet the road remained shrouded in uncertainty. Through the corridors of high school and the lecture halls of college, I watched as many turned their backs on their demons, cloaked in denial, while some clung to frail crutches of their own making. Bearing witness to such tales, I steered toward a degree in Psychology. But when the ink was dry on my diploma from Piedmont College, the path was still veiled, so I paused. That summer, in the company of a friend, I met a boy of sixteen, perched anxious upon a couch. His tale was one of escape from the talons of abuse. The next dawn, he spoke to the law of the shadows in his own home. I found myself standing at the threshold of that house, voicing my concerns to the officers, a fresh graduate of Psychology. The law, bound by its own limits, asked me to parley with the parents. Their words were nervous, their son painted as a trickster, embroiling outsiders in their "simple" family quarrels. It was in that moment, the seed of social work took root in me.

Yet another pillar of this sacred labor is social justice. A society claims to cherish the individual, grieving the lost, yet clinging to the vestiges of old ways that stifle true singularity. If we mourn the departed, why this relentless march toward sameness? I stand apart, refusing to bind myself to the mold of others. Through school and beyond, I stood in defiance of social wrongs. My hair bore the colors of rebellion, my attire a testament to self, my ears adorned in defiance of tradition. I staked my claim with the GSBA, stood against the tide of racism and discrimination, and I shall not cease. For in the heart of social justice, beats the rhythm of my soul, and against injustice, I shall always rise.

In the quiet hours when the world slumbers, there lies a disorder that steals the night away like a thief in the shadows. Insomnia, they call it. And in the pages of this discourse, we delve into the tangled web of the Biological and Sociocultural models, casting light on the restless dark. The biological model speaks in the tongue of genetics and the nuances of medical science, its gaze fixed on the inherited intricacies of our being. Meanwhile, the sociocultural model turns its eye to the vast tapestry of human interaction, to the interplay of race, ethnicity, and the weight of socioeconomic chains. This examination of insomnia walks the line between these worlds, tracing the path of research that seeks to unravel and clarify. Each study chosen stands as a solitary figure, its strengths and flaws laid bare beneath the scrutiny of critique.

Sleep disorders, those spectral maladies that haunt the night, are no simple matter. They may stride forth as primary afflictions or lurk beneath the surface, tied to the mind's other torments. Dyssonmias and Parasomnias, they are called. The former wrestles with the act of sleep itself, the latter with the strange occurrences that transpire in that realm. Primary Insomnia, Primary Hypersomnia, Narcolepsy—they are as specters named, each with its own tale of woe. And while the Dyssonmias grapple with the very act of surrendering to sleep, the Parasomnias hold court in the domain of nightmares and wandering phantoms. The mind, with its Axis I and Axis II disorders, casts its own long shadow over the world of sleep, and in this review, we turn our gaze to insomnia, ever in the context of these models.

In the realm of biology, where genes are the architects of fate, sleep disorders find their roots. In the depths of the hypothalamus, neurons, like sentinels, hold sway over the borderlands of sleep and wakefulness. A study, conducted with mice as its subjects, reveals the presence of GABAB receptors on these neurons, silent arbiters of the sleep-wake cycle. The GABAA receptor, when stirred, beckons sleep to the weary, but when silenced, it ushers in tranquility and slumber. The GABAB agonist, baclofen, extends the hours of rest, a promise whispered to the human soul. Such findings suggest a kinship between man and beast, a shared lineage of genetic and environmental threads. Within this lies a cautionary tale: the absence of this receptor may rob one of the peace of sleep, leaving them adrift in the waking world. The sociocultural echoes of this revelation speak of inherited burdens, of sleep unraveled by the unseen hand of fate, casting long shadows over the pursuits of life—be it in the fields of learning, labor, or the mundane rhythm of the everyday.

At University Park, I've found myself tethered to the earth for nigh on two and a half years, a span of semesters that stretch and fold like the plains of a desolate land. The campus itself a vast expanse, where the burden of traversing its breadth weighs heavily on students like myself, a pilgrimage from east to west. Freshman year saw me housed in East Halls, a dormitory perched on the edge of the campus world, beyond which lay the stadium and Bryce Jordan Center, specters in the distance. To venture from Stuart Hall to the center, to Willard amidst the heart of it all, took near a half-hour when the heavens unleashed their wrath, which they oft do in State College. An alum, not so distant in years, recounted days when East Halls lay beyond a barren expanse. Now, filled with fields and edifices, the campus stretches its sinews ever tauter, making passage a trial. The bicycle, then, is the answer, a savior in spokes. Yet alone it cannot suffice. The riders must embrace it, and the paths must yield to their wheels.

A friend, a prodigal to the saddle, spoke of the bicycle's allure. "Bikes are great," he confessed, as if recalling a lost lover. "For years, it seemed folly to ride, but it is the only way." In the churn of pedals and breath, one finds a journey many miles fueled by mere oats and resolve. Like many, I dwell beyond the campus bounds, as far as the dorms themselves. A wise choice it was to procure a bicycle, for to Thomas building I must go, a trek of twenty-five minutes on foot reduced to five by the grace of a swift pedal. Yet Pollock Road, the straight course to Thomas, is a treacherous vein, fraught with trials for man and machine alike. There is merit in walking, a journey of contemplation, yet time is a cruel master. Without the bike, my steps would be my sole recourse, a daily march to Thomas stealing precious minutes, hours from my week. Time I cannot spare, spent in the ceaseless rhythm of the walk.

In the bleak pages of Aldous Huxley's vision, there lies a world where the iron grip of technology entwined with the sinews of capitalism forges a dystopia of chilling precision. Brave New World stands as a testament to the collective's triumph over the soul of the individual, where the people, from the cradle, are bred to chase the fleeting ghost of happiness above all else. They walk as pawns upon a board vast and inscrutable, their lives penned by the hand of the World Controller who whispers a single creed. Through the lens of Marxist theism, the specter of suspicion looms large, drawing a line from the author's time to ours, where the machinery of economy ticks ever onward. The lexicon of Marxism—homogeny, reification—echoes through the corridors of Huxley's prose, a commentary on the fractures within the new world he saw rising.

Capitalism is laid bare, a satire sharpened by the Marxist notion of false consciousness. The common folk, blind to the chains that bind them to the wheel of economic fortune, seek only their own gain, their eyes turned from the truth of their condition. Ideology weaves its net tight around the proletariat, the laborers, seen in the conditioning of Brave New World's inhabitants. The Deltas, the Gammas, their wills hollowed out, taught in sleep to consume, to spend, to seek indulgence above all else, are puppets to the World Controller's design. Hegemony, the silent dominion of one class over another, holds them in thrall, unaware of the bars of their gilded cage, yet they buy into the creed of capitalism, consumerism. The Alphas, the Betas, gifted with awareness, do little more than acquiesce, save for a lone Bernard who dares to question. In the interactions across these social divides, the tale reveals the shadow of capitalistic oppression, a theme ripe for dissection.

In such a world, connections falter, and individuals become ghosts of themselves. Huxley's narrative, stark and unyielding, paints his characters as figures in a landscape, their depths unfathomed, their essence obscured. Perhaps, Huxley muses, it is the union of technology and capitalism that robs a man of his will, his voice. Love is an echo, emotion a shadow, their interactions shallow, the men’s talk of women reduced to object and form, the women’s talk of encounters shameless and bare. Each class, snug in its rung upon the ladder, reflects the socioeconomic chains of capitalism. Their unyielding obedience to community, a reflection of Marxist beliefs, speaks of the proletariat's false sense of superiority, as they consume, obey, march in step with their brethren.

In the years that have passed since I first stepped into that classroom at CBC and listened to the lectures on Islam, a quiet storm has brewed in the way the world grapples with the faith of a billion souls. In those discussions, fierce as the desert wind, we grappled with the question of Islam’s nature. Is it a faith of the sword or one of peace? This inquiry echoes more insistently now with the passage of time. The world has looked upon the smoldering ruins of towers in New York and watched how the media’s gaze has shifted from an unyielding glare to an embrace compelled by tolerance, a strange dance of acceptance and suspicion. In those days of ash and fire, who would have dreamed a man named Barack Obama, with whispers of a Muslim lineage, might aspire to the highest office in the land?

The life of the Prophet, Muhammad, is a tapestry woven with threads both light and dark. The tales spun of him often seem at odds with the evidences of history. It was said that he bent tribes to his will, wielding faith as a blade to carve out a new world. Yet the pages of his biography paint him as a saint misunderstood, a martyr for a cause greater than himself. It is told that he did not demand conversion at the point of a sword, but rather the truth of his words drew men to him as iron to a lodestone.

There is an uncanny echo in his acts and those of another man from long ago, a carpenter’s son who walked the shores of Galilee. Stories of Muhammad multiplying mutton and milk for forty men call to mind the loaves and fishes, and I wonder if the pen sought to recast him as a humble prophet, a man of miracles who needed no proofs but lived in the fullness of truth. Such tales, to me, seem a shadow of the greater light, a reflection seeking to claim the brilliance of Christ’s life and deeds.

The accounts in his biography often speak of witnesses, of those who came willingly into the fold of Islam. Yet these stories are like whispers carried on the wind, always heard from another’s lips and never firsthand. Their aim is to bolster belief, yet to me, they strip the stories of their flesh, leaving them bare and wanting.

What unsettles me most is the effort to lift Muhammad to heights of sanctity, to paint him as a paragon of virtue and humility. History tells a tale that diverges from this image, and I wonder if those who follow him know the fullness of his path to power. The truth, like the desert sands, shifts and changes, elusive to those who seek it.

In the shadow of time’s passing, the words and ways of Jesus, once clear as a river running beneath the vast sky, were soon left upon the shores of history. As the ages turned, Christianity, like a great tree growing wild, branched away from the source of its seed. One may observe in the wide sweep of history a faith drifting from its beginnings, the echoes of its past dim and distant. In the world of today, there rises a restless awakening, an urge towards something new and yet old. The traditionalists hold fast, clutching the teachings passed to them from their forebears, but their grip may not suffice to steer the course of the whole. Amongst the faithful, a deepening sense of history shall bloom in the years to come. A hunger shall stir to separate the doctrines layered upon Christianity through the ages from the essence of the man who walked the earth in its name. It is whispered in the winds of time that this journey backward may span decades, even centuries. Yet its end is written in the stars: a great reversal shall unfold, a return to origins. A movement shall rise, peeling away the layers of doctrine as if turning back the hands of a clock, leaving bare the simple truth that Jesus bestowed upon humankind, untouched by later minds. As this tide sweeps across the lands of America and Europe, drawing multitudes to worship as in the days of old, the church will stand firm as a beacon. But with the theological clock wound back, the multitude of Christian beliefs shall converge into a singular, harmonious voice. Across regions, denominations, and divisions of all kinds, differences shall dissolve into unity. History is a tapestry of reversals. Once, the Roman Empire cast Christians into the shadows of persecution, only to later become a bastion of their faith. Our own nation has seen the chains of slavery give way to the rise of African-American leadership. The coming reversion will unfold upon the stage of Christianity, unraveling the tapestry of time in search of its source, smoothing the wrinkles of diversity. This path shall be paved by a new reading of Jesus’ words, not as the letter of the law but as the poetry of metaphor. And so, what has transpired since Jesus walked the earth? In the annals of history, there lies Judaism, the bedrock from which Christianity sprang. Monotheism, the divine revelations, and the authority of the Hebrew scriptures formed its core long before the Romans laid claim to Jerusalem in 63 B.C.E. The Jewish people were not a single voice but many—Sadducees, Pharisees, Essenes, Zealots, and the multitude of common folk, each with their own song.

In the desolate heart of Sinclair's Jungle, the truth of man's greed is laid bare, stripped of pretense or mercy. Beneath the veneer of civilization lies a selfish core, a hunger that drives men to seek their own fortune while casting aside those beneath them. The great factories rise like monoliths against the sky, steely and indifferent, their masters concerned only with the glory of their own empires. They care not for the collateral damage, for the lives trampled in their relentless pursuit of progress. Sinclair's prose cuts like a knife, drawing a stark image of the world they create. "The line of the buildings stood clear-cut and black against the sky; here and there out of the mass rose the great chimneys, with the river of smoke streaming away to the end of the world." It is a world suffocating under the weight of its own ambition, the air thick with smoke and the ground stained with the refuse of life.

The captains of industry are blind to the suffering of their workers, seeing only the glint of a dollar. They are men without loyalty, their decency traded for profit. "So from the top to bottom the place is simply a seething cauldron of jealousies and hatreds; there is no loyalty or decency anywhere about it, there is no place in it where a man counted for anything against a dollar." They drive their workers like cattle, merciless and unyielding, casting them aside without a thought when they no longer serve their purpose. In the era of The Jungle, laws are scarce and justice a distant dream, leaving the laborers at the mercy of their masters. They toil in squalor, live in misery, and die in obscurity, forgotten by the world they helped build. The unions, meant to be their salvation, are often as corrupt as the system they oppose, preying on the very people they claim to protect. Sinclair lays bare the harsh reality, the workers akin to slaves in this modern age, "Here is a population, low-class and mostly foreign, hanging always on the verge of starvation and dependent for its opportunities of life upon the whim of men every bit as brutal and unscrupulous as the old-time slave drivers; under such circumstances, immorality is exactly as inevitable, and as prevalent, as it is under the system of chattel slavery." It is a tale of darkness, of a world where hope is a flickering candle against the unrelenting night.

In the shadowed corridors of literary history, Poe's "Dream-Land" stands as one of his own favored works, a testament to the macabre and the ethereal. In this poem, the name "Thulé" arises twice, at lines 6 and 56, a nod that Mabbott traces back to Virgil. That ancient poet spoke of an island northward, a place where the known world frayed into mystery and myth. But more than Virgil's distant shores, it is the Germanic whispers that capture Poe's imagination. His fascination with the Teutonic authors is well known, and in this, one finds a connection to Goethe, the illustrious scribe of "Faust."

Karl J. Arndt, in his scholarly musings over Poe and Goethe, draws a line between them, suggesting an echo of imitation. Goethe, he who penned the tragic tale of "The King of Thulé," a king bereft and broken by the death of his queen, clinging to a goblet that spoke of loss and longing. That same king, in his sorrow, cast the goblet into the sea and found his own end upon a lonely cliff. There is in this tale a shadowy reflection of Poe's own "Dream-Land," perhaps a dark twin born of grief and the solace of drink, mirroring Poe's own demons.

In the Oxford tome of English letters, Goethe is celebrated for "Faust," a drama split across the years of his life, culminating in the year of his passing, 1832. And within this work, the mournful tale of "The King of Thulé" finds its place. It is a tale of desolation, much like the landscape of Poe's dreamscape, where the air is thick with ghosts and the world is drained of its colors. So it is that "The King of Thulé" and "Dream-Land" might be read as twin paths through the same somber forest.

Poe, too, speaks of Thule, twice in his collected works. In "The Pit and the Pendulum," he mentions "ultima Thule," and in "Dream-Land," the term bookends the poem, framing it in the same mythic isolation. It is as if Poe walked the same spectral paths as Goethe's king, both haunted by phantoms of the past. For Poe, Goethe was a figure of significance, known to him perhaps through the lens of Tennyson, another poet of renown whom Poe admired. In the echoes of Tennyson's respect, Poe might have found the Germanic voice of Goethe, resonating through the years and the shadows of his own dark imaginings.

In the land of sun and promise where the Pacific beats its endless dirge upon the shore, there lies a question of law and consequence. A woman, Jennifer Palmer by name, found herself lain low upon the hard tiles of a grocery store, felled not by fate but by the slick betrayal of applesauce. The law of California, with its statutes and codes, turns upon itself to ask if such a fall might yield more than the recompense for her pain. Might it, in its turning, render punitive damages upon the keeper of the store, one Paul Martin, who sat idly with his dinner as the spill lay unheeded?

The judge, a figure of solemn judgment, may hold his hand from dismissing Palmer's claim so easily. For the law demands that to seek punitive damages, one must show that the actions of the accused were not only careless but carried with them a willful and knowing disregard for the harm they would wreak. The conduct must be shown as despicable, a word heavy with moral weight. Palmer, with her counsel, will argue that Martin should have seen the harm coiled in that spill, for it was not the first of its kind. In the months before her fall, others had met the floor with equal violence, and yet Martin did nothing.

On that day, the thirteenth of October, 2009, the clock marked five in the afternoon when a young man named Rich Wayne, servant of D&D Markets, spoke to his superior, Paul Martin, of the applesauce's peril. Martin, breaking his bread, dismissed it as a minor annoyance. A quarter-hour passed and another voice, Mary J. Haddigan's, rose with the same warning. Martin's reply was unchanged. The clock moved on and at half-past five, Palmer fell.

The courts of California allow for punitive damages to be sought when a wrong is done with oppression, fraud, or malice. The law paints malice as an act intended to harm or, failing intent, an act so vile as to be done with a conscious disregard for the safety of others. In the case of Taylor v. Super. Ct. of Los Angeles Co., the court spoke of malice as a thing aware of its own danger yet choosing still to proceed. In the quiet halls of justice, these words will echo as Palmer seeks recompense for the injury borne of Martin's neglect.

She had always felt a want like a hunger in her soul, a yearning that would not be sated. It had crept upon her at fourteen, the tender age when one begins to step into the shadowed paths of adolescent life. By seventeen it still lingered, unresolved and unrelenting. She had come to reckon it wasn't a thing she sought but a someone, yet no boy had ever stirred her heart. Suitors had approached, stumbling over themselves in the awkward dance of courtship, but none held her interest. She found herself pondering this enigma, wondering what peculiarity of spirit could cause such a deviation from the expected course of a young girl's life. She spun theories like a spider spins its web, but none held her fast. So she continued onward, ever questioning the nature of her desires.

The days at home were a gentle affair. Her parents were folk of quiet dispositions, their lives free of discord. Rarely did cross words pass between them, and scarcely ever with their daughter. Their disputes, if they could be called that, revolved around her fierce independence, the unyielding spirit that defined her. She was a child of calm souls, yet she brought a liveliness that countered their placid ways, endearing her to many with a charmed personality and a genuine kindness.

Yet today the tranquility was shattered. As she wandered the house in search of some spark to light her imagination, a sharp cry pierced the air from the kitchen. A sound that was her mother's voice. Panic gripped her as she rushed to the scene, her heart pounding with dread. "Mom?! Mom, what's wrong?!" she cried out, finding her mother sprawled upon the floor, her face twisted in pain, breathless whispers of "Ow" escaping her lips. The daughter knelt beside her, a hand reaching out in desperate aid. "Ouch... swee - ty, I... need you to take me to - the hospital." The words were strained, squeezed out through the agony, and the daughter knew her mother suffered greatly. "Okay Mom, just tell me where I can pick you up." Her mother gestured weakly, and at that moment, the girl felt gratitude for the strength she had honed through practice. She gathered her mother in her arms, bore her to the car, and laid her in the back as if she were laying down the most precious of burdens.

The hospital loomed with its scent of antiseptic and the omnipresent air of dread. But the girl was unfazed by these things, her mind consumed with the singular focus of aiding her mother. She carried the injured woman inside, her voice calling out for the aid of the doctors. Faces tightened with concern surrounded them, and swiftly a rolling bed was brought forth, her mother gently placed upon it. They whisked her away to the sterile haven where ailments are met with care, and the daughter was left in the waiting room, alone with her worry.

Her mother had taken a tumble from a stepping stool, reaching high for a vase nestled in the uppermost cabinet of their home.

In the quiet march of time, the study sought to unravel a truth about the Mediterranean way of eating, a diet of the ancients, transmuted into a modern form they called the aMed diet. It was a beacon in the heart of uncertainty, proposing that those who walked its path might find themselves less beset by the spectral hands of chronic heart disease and the stillness of stroke. This aMed diet, a shadow of its ancestral form, was a tapestry woven with the fruits of the earth, the proteins of plants save for the humble potato, and the bounties of the sea. It eschewed the heavy hand of saturated fats for the grace of monounsaturated oils and allowed the gentle touch of alcohol in moderation.

In the annals of prospective studies, there lay evidence of this diet's power, its inverse dance with the specter of mortality, both total and cardiovascular. Intervention too had shown the diet's might, surpassing the meager offerings of low-fat regimes in the battles of weight and the alchemy of cholesterol in the bulwarks of obesity. Yet the stroke, that sudden thief of vitality, had eluded these chronicles until now.

The study cast its net over the lives of 74,886 women, aged between 38 and 63 years, untouched by the ravages of cardiovascular disease and diabetes, members of that grand congregation known as the Nurses' Health Study. Six times, from the year of our Lord 1984 to the year 2004, the learned authors drew forth the aMed diet scores from the women's own accounts of their sustenance, a ritual of self-report known as the food frequency questionnaire. Through two decades, the steadfast majority stayed true, their declarations subject to the scrutiny of validation studies. Reports of heart disease, of fatal heart disease, and stroke were sifted from the chaff of uncertainty by the hands of medical record, autopsy, or the finality of death certificates. Where such records lay absent, the cases were deemed probable, a shadow of certainty, yet included nonetheless.

To lessen the noise of random chance and better echo the truth of long-term dietary intake, the scholars calculated averages, drawing from the well of repeated measures over the years. Confounders, those tricksters that might mislead the unwary, were accounted for, adjusting for age, the smoke of tobacco, the weight of body mass, the tides of menopause and its hormonal travelers, the tablets of multivitamins, the indulgence of alcohol, the vigor of physical activity, and the salve of aspirin.

The statisticians employed Cox proportional-hazard modeling, a tool to peer into the relationship between the aMed score and the specters of heart disease and stroke, casting separate nets for the fatal and the nonfatal.

In the quiet tallying of two decades, they found that those who adhered more closely to the Mediterranean path, scoring higher on the aMed scale, had fewer encounters with the shadows of heart disease and stroke. In those years, 2391 new cases of heart disease arose, 1763 strokes were counted, and 1077 souls were claimed by the combined force of heart disease and stroke. Women in the upper echelons of the aMed score knew less of these shadows than their counterparts in the lower rungs, the relative risk standing at 0.71, a testament to the diet's quiet strength.

The sign stands alone like a monolith on the street corner, a piece of cardboard held aloft by Ellen Page, the actress from that film Juno, her eyes reflecting something far off and distant. On the sign, a message scrawled in black Sharpie: Hitler is alive in Burma. Burma, or Myanmar as some call it now, a land under the iron grip of a military junta since the cold coup of 1962. In the year of 2007, the streets bore witness to a stirring, a gathering of voices that had lain dormant for a decade. Monks in their saffron robes, a color that would name their revolution, marched in defiance, their chants rising like smoke against the oppressive sky. The people watched, waited, and then joined, their patience waning as the junta's tolerance turned to violence. The monasteries, sacred and silent, became battlegrounds, the military storming in like wolves among sheep. Foreign eyes were not welcome, and those who dared to look, like the Japanese photographer Kenji Nagai, paid with their lives. The official count stands at thirteen dead, but whispers from a defector, Colonel Hla Win, tell of thousands, their bodies hidden from the world's view.

This is the world we know, where power seeks to silence the whispers of dissent with the iron fist of history. The Romans, emperors by divine right, ruled with a will as hard as the stones of their roads. In Japan, the emperors claimed divinity, leading their people through the ages of swords and technology. Across the ocean, the president named George, his counsel with preachers of ignorance, a strange echo of those who came before.

The tales of tyranny are many, like shadows cast long by the setting sun. In 1989, in the vastness of Tiananmen, they gathered, those who dared to dream of freedom. The numbers of the dead are lost in the fog of war, the truth a casualty as much as the bodies. Rwanda, a land torn by hatred, saw the Hutu rise against the Tutsi, the blood of innocents spilled in a government-sanctioned madness. And then there was Hitler, the architect of an era of darkness, his Reich spreading like a plague until the world itself burned.

These are the stories of our time and times past, the cycles of power and blood that turn like the seasons, unyielding and eternal.

The long shadow of Duke Ellington stretches across the vast expanse of jazz, a testament to his enduring presence and the artful hand he wielded in shaping his orchestra. His touch upon the piano is as a whisper in the night, subtle and pervasive, but as a composer, he spun tapestries of sound rich and intricate, each thread woven with the skill of a master craftsman. Ellington built a stage upon which soloists might dance, unfettered and free, yet also wrote with the precision of a watchmaker, crafting phrases that called forth the unique timbre of each player, drawing out the heart of the orchestra itself. It was in this alchemy of sound that he forged something new, sounds that stood apart, that sang with their own voice.

The Grove Music dictionary speaks of Ellington’s innovation, naming Creole Love Call as a testament to his use of the voice as an instrument of jazz, a voice that paints with broad strokes, unhindered by the fetters of words. This piece is a tapestry, six choruses in all, each a departure and a return:

Chorus one, a call and response between voice and reeds, begins smooth as silk, only to grow ragged and raw. The second chorus is a muted trumpet, twisting the melody like a river bends, blue notes stretching out like shadows at sundown. A clarinet then takes the stage, soaring high as a bird on the wind, the piano beneath it an undercurrent of syncopation. The fourth chorus brings the band in full, echoing the call and response, brass and reeds entwined in a dance. The fifth chorus climbs to its peak, the reeds now leading, high and wild, as the brass and rhythm hold the time. The sixth, a return to the beginning, the voice now growling, a beast of an instrument. A brief tag, a vocal run, the trombone a discordant end.

Ellington’s use of the voice as a brush to paint tone upon the canvas of his work is but one stroke in his legacy. In Hot and Bothered, recorded but a year later, Ellington’s hand is as precise as ever, orchestrating with an ear for the colors of sound. A dialogue between “Bubber” Miley’s muted trumpet and Baby Cox’s scat singing, the vocal strains of the trumpet and the instrumental notes in Cox’s voice weave together, rich and full. It Don’t Mean a Thing (If It Ain’t Got That Swing) takes these ideas further still, Joe “Tricky Sam” Nanton introducing the melody on muted trombone, a staple of Ellington’s orchestra, his sound a cornerstone upon which the music is built.

In the vast theater of the natural world, creatures evolve as if guided by the hands of some unseen clockmaker, their changes both mysterious and inevitable. The constraints of this evolution, the unseen walls that shape their path, remain as elusive as the shadows at dusk. D’Arcy Thompson, in the year of our Lord 1917, mused that the language of mathematics had scarcely touched the simplest of organic forms, and the echo of his words lingers even now. Yet in recent times, the lens of mathematical modeling peers into the very essence of mollusk skeletogenesis, tracing the lineage of these creatures through the ages as Raup and Stanley once did in the year 1981. Our inquiry delves into the realm of Prunum, where mathematical modeling entwines with experimentation to uncover the secrets of evolutionary change, both in direction and magnitude.

We turn to the x-ray's cold gaze upon the Prunum species, where the language of numbers delineates the parameters of skeletal form, feeding them into the maw of a program named CerioShell, born of Stone’s mind in 1995. From this crucible emerge visions of shells both imagined and real, their morphologies whispering of the boundaries that bind Prunum’s evolutionary dance. These findings, in concert with the hands-on touch of experiment and the art of description, seek to unravel the tapestry of macroevolution within this lineage.

The shell, a testament to time and transformation, is a tube that winds its way through the ages, twisting upon itself in its eternal spiral. These revolutions, these whorls, encircle an imaginary axis, a pillar known as the columella. The whorls grow at varying paces, divided by the suture, a seam that marks their passage. The final and largest whorl, the body whorl, stands apart from the spire, composed of the whorls that precede it. At the spire’s tip lies the apex, and at its opposite end, the base. The creature within extends through the aperture, the gateway of its shell.

Gaze upon these shells from every angle: the apical, the basal, the apertural, and the abapertural. In the usual view, the aperture faces the observer, the apex reaching skyward. To count the whorls, one must peer from the apex, discern the first suture’s beginning, and draw a line that cleaves the shell. From this line, the whorls are counted, estimated to the quarter of a whorl.

Each shell is a chronicle, a story of apertures traveling through the corridors of time and space, as the creature builds its home. This journey can be traced, mapped with coordinates marking each whorl’s aperture, its radii both horizontal and vertical.

Such a path can be rendered in the language of graphs and equations. And once this mathematical tapestry is woven, it becomes possible to alter the course of the mollusk’s skeletogenesis, changing the very nature of its creation.

In that sprawling archipelago where the sun rises over endless seas, the rate at which the very breath of newborns is stilled has hung constant, a grim measure unyielding across a decade's passage. While Indonesia strides toward the distant light of the Millennium's promises, the path for mothers and their babes remains shrouded, the goals unmet and the hands of the clock relentless. Beneath the surface, the reasons for this faltering become clear—an ailing system calls for healing, not mere patches upon its wounds.

And yet, there are signs of life, for the cries of birth now more often echo with the presence of skilled hands. Seventy-two of every hundred births now find such guidance, though it is a guidance of tradition. Old ways persist in the guise of midwives, unable to stem the tide when blood flows too freely, leaving a trail of mothers claimed by hemorrhage. It is a promise half-kept, a statistic that whispers of progress yet hides the truth of the road still to tread. Meanwhile, the young suffer in silence, fewer now seeking the healer’s touch for the scourge of diarrheal affliction, and in postnatal care, the story is yet unwritten, incomplete and troubling in its scarcity.

In the cities, beneath the concrete and steel, the knife of the surgeon finds its place, though in the rural lands, it remains a stranger. Four in a hundred births see the cesarean's deliverance, a number that betrays the inequity between the bustling urban and the quiet rural. The chasm between the rich and the poor yawns wide, a testament to the burden of coins that weigh heavy in the hands of the destitute, blocking their path to healing.

As the nation ponders the road ahead, a question looms like a specter—how to mend that which is broken? Should the focus be on the specific, the immediate, or should it lay upon the broader canvas of the health system entire? The allure of the targeted, the swift, is undeniable. To seize upon a single thread and pull, to watch it unravel with purpose, is a tempting thought. But beware the cost, for to pour all into one vessel is to leave others dry, and the weavers of health will flock to where the gold is bright. The tale of one illness finds its echo in the neglect of another, a dance of resources uncoordinated, a tangle of forms and papers that stifle the very breath of progress.

In the expanse of a century, the catalog of Popular Music has swelled to encompass so many divergent strains and offshoots that one might find it a futile endeavor to name them all. And therein lies the tangle, for each genre—rap, rock, country, jazz, folk, to scribble but a few—has given rise to its own broods of sub-genres, and those to sub-sub-genres, a lineage unbroken and unending. Heavy Metal rock, in particular, stands as a testament to this evolution, having burgeoned into one of the most variegated and expressive branches of popular music over the past four decades. Its expressiveness lies in the spectrum of emotions it conjures, though the shadows often find their home therein. Its diversity is a testament to its malleability, a trait recognized early by those who wielded it, who bent it to their own designs, and so begat a multitude of sub-genres, a cycle that endures to this day.

We find ourselves now amid a labyrinth of heavy metal, where the myriad niches defy simple classification. It has absorbed the essence of other genres, yet like all things, it has its origins. To truly grasp the metal that permeates today's airwaves, one must first delve into the metal movement itself, for it is a movement, a force, rather than a mere genre.

Metal is, in essence, a movement clad in darkness. It is a music of excess—excess in bass, in volume, in ferocity, in spectacle. It casts aside the primitive for the complex; the musicians within its fold wield their instruments with a mastery that echoes through their creations. And as it may come as no revelation, metal is a movement that walks hand in hand with the specter of drugs. The psychedelic surge of the mid-seventies drove its adherents to the brink, birthing records that traversed the realms of the strange and the surreal, each note an echo of the substances that inspired them. It embraced the dark, the visceral, a novelty in a world where much of popular music shied from such shadows. The later progeny of metal drew from this well, finding kinship with the Romantic Era's own dalliance with darkness, visceral and unyielding. The lyrics, etched in darkness, are the heart of this movement.

These words from Helter Skelter reveal the Beatles' shadowed side. They chart the crests and troughs, ostensibly a nod to the influence of drugs. Some hold this song as the harbinger of Heavy Metal, born of a challenge, a riposte to a Rolling Stones tune that tread on the heavier, unlit paths. The Beatles, not to be outdone, inscribed it onto The White Album, a testament to their own capacity for heaviness.

In the years before the surrealists cast their visions upon canvas, there was Henri Rousseau, a man who fashioned dreams from the very fabric of his soul. His painting, The Dream, born in 1910, stands not merely as an image of a woman awash in the mysteries of a dreamt jungle but as a testament to Rousseau’s own aspirations, both spoken and unspoken, as an artist. He longed for the nod of approval, the embrace of his peers, and the applause of those who knew art's language. Yet, he stood at a crossroad, a silent war within him, torn between two paths: to tread the well-worn road of conformity, painting in a manner that would grant him entry into the hallowed halls of acceptance, or to carve his own passage, to be a beacon of singularity in a world of echoes.

To understand The Dream, one must first walk through the corridors of Rousseau’s life. Born on May 21, 1844, in the town of Laval, northwest France, the son of a tinsmith and dealer of hardware who thrived in the modest comfort of bourgeois life, young Henri knew not the teachings of art’s masters. Instead, he toiled in the service of the state, a gabelou they called him, a collector of tolls, though the world remembers him as a douanier, a customs man. His life bore the scars of grief, the passing of Clémence, his first wife, and the loss of eight children, leaving him with Julia, his daughter, and sorrow so deep it sought the solace of a brush and canvas. Unlike those who romanticized the peasant’s plight, Rousseau painted not with sentimentality but with the earnest dreams of a man of his time and place.

Rousseau’s yearning for acceptance in the art world is a tale of context and circumstance. Untrained in the refined techniques, he began his journey at an age when others had already made their mark. In the shadow of giants, he labored, seeking his place as Matisse and the like carved their own legends. In Modern French Painters, Jan Gordon speaks of this dichotomy, the contrast between Rousseau and Matisse, each driven by different demons. Matisse, wary of the banal, sought to break free from it, while Rousseau, with every stroke, hoped to weave a tapestry so conventional that it might unlock the gates of the Artiste Français.

In the quiet spaces between the lines of the world, there lies an understanding that needs no words. Many a mind has sought to draw the lines between the good and the beautiful, to find where truth and beauty meet. There is something deep and unspoken that ties these together, as if whispered by the earth itself. Keats, in his eternal reflection upon a Grecian urn, spoke of beauty and truth as one and the same. And so, it seems that the heart knows the good and the beautiful without the need for lessons or learning. These are not taught in the schools of man but come as whispers from the world itself. 

Ethics and aesthetics, they do not command but rather reveal. They do not dictate the path but show the way the light falls upon it. We study them not to lay down laws but to understand the heart of what makes a thing right or a piece of art worthy. In our critiques, we wander through fields of thought, unable to capture fully the essence of what we chase, for some things are beyond the reach of words. The Mona Lisa's smile, it holds secrets that elude the grasp of explanation, as if to say, there's just something about it. 

Words fall short, as O'Connor knew, for what is in the heart of a story cannot be captured by mere statement. We speak of art, of morals, and yet there is always something left unsaid, a shadow that dances just beyond the edge of the firelight. Wittgenstein spoke of ethics as beyond expression, and in that, we find a truth that connects the beauty we see to the good we feel, a bond that is woven into the fabric of our being.

In the realm where soul touches soul, art and morality stand together, both felt more deeply than they can be explained. They speak to us in a language of the heart, in the quiet voice of what is beyond the veil. Literature, more than any other, carries within it the pulse of morality, the whisper of values that echo through life itself. It is here, in the pages that turn with the wind of time, where we find the weight of what is right, the light of what is beautiful. And so it is, the stories we tell, they are the bridges between what is and what ought to be, between the seen and the unseen, between the good and the beautiful.

In the land of Germany as we now see it, there lies a strength borne from unity, a tapestry of culture that stretches from the shadowed alps of München to the windswept shores of the Baltic at Kiel. This same spirit courses through the veins of Köln along the Rhine and threads its way to the Saxon heart of Dresden on the Elbe. A culture so singular yet woven from threads of varied tribes and distant echoes, it stands as a testament to the many sources from which Germany has sprung.

Germania, the cradle of the German people, holds within its name a mystery that has long beguiled the minds of scholars and historians alike. Tacitus spun a tale of the Tungrians, a tribe of ancient repute, claiming they bore the name Germans before they dared the crossing of the Rhine to clash with the Gauls. Julius Caesar, in his chronicles of conquest, spoke of the Germans, borrowing a name from the very foes he sought to subdue, a name that marked the divide between the known and the unconquered. The Gauls had their word, Germanus, to set apart those not yet brought to heel. Some wise in etymology suggest the name arose from a neighbor’s tongue, a word of demarcation or perhaps from the spear, the ger, wielded with fearsome might, or from the Old Irish garim, a shout to pierce the air, a testament to their clamor in battle.

Tacitus, in the year of our Lord ninety-eight, penned his thoughts on the origins of these people in De Origine et situ Germanorum. He saw them as a race untouched by the migrations and minglings of others, rooted, steadfast. “For who among the travelers would leave the sunlit lands of Asia or Africa for the wilds of Germany, with its unkind skies and somber ways, unless it were his homeland?”

And what Roman would forsake the opulence of Rome for Germania? Not the Romans, not then. They sent their legions to the edges of Germania, seeking riches and skirmishes, yet their hearts longed for the marble halls of their empire. The Germanic tribes, appearing as shadows at the empire's border, traded in goods borne of the earth and lent their swords to Roman legions, biding their time as history unfolded its relentless march.

In the dimming light of Illyria, where the shadows of men and women entwine in the dance of deception, the play Twelfth Night casts a somber truth. Disguise, a tool of cunning, serves its master well in orchestrating the symphony of deceit, yet in its final act demands a reckoning. A soul, clad in borrowed garb too long, risks dissolution in the masquerade, a ghost adrift between reality and illusion. To tear away the veil is to stand exposed, alienated from those who once walked beside you. Thus, the heart must choose its tether—self-preservation or the fragile bonds of kinship. For some, the unmasking is met with silent acceptance, yet others take affront, scorning the artifice with wounded pride.

In the realm of gender, this deception weaves a more complex tapestry, unraveling questions of identity and the impetus to forsake one's true visage. Viola, cast upon these shores, dons the guise of a man—a shield against the world's predations. “I’ll bring you to a captain in this town/ Where lie my maiden weeds, by whose gentle help/ I was preserved to serve this noble count…” she confides, her voice a whisper in the gathering dusk. But in this guise, she finds herself severed from the sisterhood, a stranger among her own. Olivia, beguiled by the semblance of a man, mistakes her heart's desire, entwining her fate with the mistaken identity of Sebastian. “Whither, my lord? Cesario, husband, stay,” she pleads, lost in the labyrinth of love and misconception. And there lies Orsino, whose words to the boy echo with unspoken longing: “Boy, thou hast said to me a thousand times/ Thou never shouldst love woman like to me.”

In the eyes of the modern, this play unfolds as a map of hidden desires, its characters ensnared by the deceptions that lay bare their heart's true yearnings. Olivia's attraction to Cesario begs the question—does the guise of masculinity alone hold her affections, or does her heart, unbidden, lean toward the feminine? Yet, Shakespeare’s hand seems not to craft a woman of such disposition, but rather to mirror the folly of an age that weighed worth by the sheen of outward appearance. Her swift shift of affection to Sebastian, and the embracing of Viola as kin, speaks to a capricious heart swayed more by visage than by essence: “A sister, you are she.” The play, then, is a mirror held to the human soul, reflecting both the folly and the truth that dwell within.

The German colonial endeavor, in its breadth and reach, wore the visage of a harsh and unforgiving master, its infamy sealed in the annals of history through the blood of the Ovaherero and Nama peoples in what was once German South West Africa. Yet to cast such a sprawling enterprise under one shadow is to overlook its disparate nature. Like the lands it claimed, the empire was a patchwork of varied policies and governance. In education, too, it was a mosaic, with each colony telling its own story. When the British laid claim to German East Africa, or Tanganyika as it was known in the year of our Lord 1919, they uncovered a realm where the tongues of the people were not foreign to learning. The Germans had left their mark, a legacy of literacy that did not go unnoticed, even in places like Kamerun where their efforts drew nods of approval from those who came after.

But in the sun-baked expanse of South West Africa, now Namibia, the tale took a different turn. Here, unlike the schools that rose in East Africa, education of the native sons and daughters was a duty laid upon the mission houses, starved of any substantial succor from the state. The government, though, did not shirk when it came to the European settlers, investing heavily in their instruction, laying down state schools and fortifying the mission schools with funds and regulations of their own devising. These choices, these paths chosen, cast long shadows across the land, shadows that lingered long after the Germans themselves had passed from sovereignty. Where elsewhere in the empire the children grew to read and write, here in South West Africa, they remained largely untouched by the light of literacy, left in the dark by a confluence of forces both seen and unseen.

This discourse seeks to unravel these threads, to delve into the motives and attitudes that shaped this divergence, drawing upon the labors of those who have documented the German educational odyssey. Much of this lore lies buried in the tongue of the Germans, penned in the days when the empire itself was a living breath. These early tomes served as chronicles of the educational landscape, while later works in the English tongue sought to compare and contrast the schooling of one colony to another, teasing out the strands that wove their distinct tapestries. Foremost among these is Cohen’s treatise on the educational paths of South West Africa and East Africa, a study that lays bare the contrasts and seeks the roots of their differences. Cohen points to the settlers, a throng of them in South West Africa, as a key to understanding why its schools were as they were.

In the eyes of the Germans, South West Africa was a land tempered by climate, more forgiving than others, though much of it lay under the dominion of the relentless desert. By the year 1913, nearly fifteen thousand souls of European descent called it home, far outnumbering those in East Africa, the next haven for settlers, where their numbers did not exceed 5,336. Here in this land, they sought to carve out a new life, and in doing so, shaped the fate of the land’s education in their image.

In the annals of time, the United States of America and Mexico stand as testament to two lands once locked in a rivalry that stretched over the better part of six decades, from the year of our Lord 1836 until the closing years of the century in 1893. The zenith of this discord found its cruel expression in the Mexican-American War of 1846-1848, wherein the United States, with fire and iron, laid claim to the territories of Texas and the vast expanses of the American Southwest. This was not the only clash. No, many skirmishes marked the years between them, their fervor only beginning to wane as the world edged toward the abyss of the First World War. The seeds of this enmity were sown in the fertile ground of conflicting beliefs and traditions, the very marrow of their peoples, and the material desires that often set men at odds with one another.

It is not a tale untold by history, this notion of neighbors bound by geography yet divided by their ambitions. Borders, drawn by the hand of man, often serve as lines of conflict as much as they do lines of demarcation. And so it was with the United States and Mexico, mirroring rivalries seen elsewhere in the world. David M. Pletcher, in his reflections, spoke of the enduring nature of American diplomatic quandaries, finding them most acutely in the lands of Mexico and Cuba. These lands, while close in miles, have oft been distant in harmony, their relations with the United States a stark contrast to the relative peace found further down the Latin American expanse.

Religion, that ancient specter, drove a wedge between these nations. Sally Frahm observed how the Americans, in the twilight of the eighteenth and the dawn of the nineteenth centuries, stood opposed to the specters of Catholicism and monarchy, much as they later would to fascism and communism.
